ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
None
practice quizzes, problem sets, concept checks, office hours, peer tutoring hours
There were also explorations that we had to do before class.
During election week, our instructor also recorded the lectures to be watched on our own time. Otherwise, the rest of the lectures were all live.
No other

Use of short pre class explorations. 
Lectures. 
Peer tutor office hours and professor office hours.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, techniques to find antiderivatives, sequences and series, polar curves, and parametric equations.
Integration, Series/Sequences, and introductions to volumes of revolutions and polar/parametric equations.
I learned how to apply Calculus concepts to various problems.
I furthered my knowledge of calculus and learned how to learn mathematical topics more efficiently than I previously could.
I definitely learned how to think on my feet and evaluate problems as they come instead of preparing for a certain type every time.
Calculus

This course helped me remember the reason why I love Mathematics. It allowed me to think deeply and creatively about approaching problems and analyzing them. This class served as a perfect QR credit as it truly focuses on quantative reasoning, and not simply Mathematics.
Material similar to AP Calculus BC: integrals, area/volume between curves, parametric & polar equations, etc.
I furthered my knowledge of calculus and reviewed the quantitative line of thinking.

I learned how to see the area and volume through the functions that describe curves. It allowed me to gain insights into how CAD programs are able to figure out the shape of something purely based on mathematical descriptions of the object.
The analytical skills required to determine the area between curves or the volumes of irregular solids.
Gained a more in-depth knowledge of single variable calculus and learned how to be more critical and analytical for different math problems.

This course taught me to think about math from a whole new perspective. From the beginning, our instructor, Dr. VandenBoom, told us that this course would teach us how to use critical thinking in a new way and apply it to real-life scenarios through mathematical concepts, and that is exactly what happened by the end of the course.
I learned the basics of integral calculus and expanded on my prior knowledge.
Math skills
To learn more the foundations of integral calculus and how it can be applied in other subject areas.
I got better at calculus and problem solving.
Learned integral calculus, including its application to polar equations and volume. The course also covered infinite sequences and series.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course is Dr. V and the amount of practice we get for midterms and the final. It could be improved by not having problem sets when we had midterms.

Strengths: Lots of practice is offered. The practice midterms/final, the concept checks, the review sessions were all very helpful to me. The organization of the course was very good. I felt like the topics flowed nicely into each other. Peer tutor session were also very helpful. 

Weaknesses: The explorations felt more like busy work at times than anything else.

Strengths: In depth and a great pace
Weaknesses: None
This course is a successful math class, but it can be easy to become unengaged in the class in the current virtual format. The general organization, however, is conducive to learning.

Strengths: I think the major strength of this course is that it allows you to seriously develop some of your math skills, and it introduces you to complex topics that you may not have come across in high school. This should be a good course if you did well in AP Calc AB

Weaknesses: MAJOR inconsistencies among the different sections in this course. I was lucky to be in a good section, but that was only after switching from a professor who seemed largely unprepared for this type of learning. Additionally, I was displeased to see the amount of students who had placed in higher level courses who were allowed to drop into this one. For them, it was essentially a review, whereas with other students, it was hard to stay afloat, which made the grading non representative of the whole.
Recorded lectures and more thoughtful instrutcion

Perhaps the only thing that could be improved would be adding a break during class as it sometimes takes a toll on students to sit on the Zoom nonstop for an hour fifteen minutes, and is not ideal to be continuous with no breaks in between for students to get up, stretch, etc..

Strengths: A lot of time between homework assignments which allows you enough time to learn the material and get help if you need it; a lot of opportunity for review before exams
Weakness: Instruction during class unclear at some times; little to no student collaboration during class
Professor Vandenboom did a fantastic job teaching this course to us all and there were ample resources available to succeed.

I liked the peer tutoring which definitely helped me a ton to learn calculus II. I think that office hours are also a great strenght as they allow for a more one-on-one lecture. I think that a weakness from the class is that their is low engagement but that is more attributed to the zoom format.

One of the weaknesses was that the types of problems we went over in class were often at a lower level of difficulty than what we were expected to do on the problem sets or on the exams. It would've been helpful if we had gone over a wider variety of problems. One of the strengths was that class was very engaging because the professor did polls throughout, so that we could solve problems on our own before he walked us through the answer.

The lectures were absolutely perfect. Dr. VandenBoom was especially great with engaging the class in his lectures, especially using the poll feature where he would write down a question on his tablet and we would solve it and enter our answer in a poll. It was a great way to judge how well you had understood the material thus far in the lecture. I don't think I would change anything about his lectures because they were great! One weakness of the course would probably be the exploration modules. Although they were a really good idea, sometimes the concepts would not be clearly explained and I wouldn't really learn much from them. They personally were not that helpful all the time as an introduction to the next lectures. However, I think that the explorations could be improved by implementing more short videos in between each question to introduce the concepts in a better way.
The strengths of this course are that it was well taught and encouraged class engagement.
Great explanations
I think that the explorations were tedious and not helpful. I also wish the lectures had been recorded so that we wouldve been able to go back and watch them again if we were confused.

I know instruction varied a lot by section and teacher. There is a weekly pset to cover material worked in class. Only some of the sections had interactive portions of the lecture where teachers checked students' understanding. Thankfully, there is a class-wide review before each test that students from all sections can join. The practice exams and solution guides were posted to canvas which helped studying at student's convenience.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The zoom polling was very nice as it allowed me to practice without fear of being called out if I was incorrect. The screen sharing with notes on the screen also helped as I am a visual learner.
The class was easy to follow and well taught, but it became a very repetitive routine.

I think that a lecture style is great for the COVID pandemic since you don't have to leave the comfort of your room. Additionally, my professor did a lot of polls during class to gauge comprehension. Added to that, I would have appreciated more help on the problem sets, though I understand those were made to push us.
Slower teaching style

In terms of gearing the course toward COVID learning, I think the instructor did a terrific job. He tried his best to allow for student participation despite it being a virtual format, and had multiple Office Hours and opportunities for one-on-one sessions if needed. He also quickly responded to emails, which has been crucial this semester.
All review sessions and class sessions should be recorded
Virtual learning, especially in math, can be challenging but the teacher did a fantastic job engaging the students through poll questions to make sure students were learning.
I think that the class could implement more features like the google jam board because taking notes everyday would get boring and make you feel unengaged.
It would've been helpful if the lectures were recorded.
The live lectures on Zoom succeeded very well. The way Dr. VandenBoom taught us was very engaging despite learning from a computer, and I don't see any way it could be improved.
Very engaging lectures

The lectures should have been recorded throughout the year. This would improve the experience of students in other timezones. Peer tutor office hours were also fixed at a specific time which might have disadvantaged some students.
I definitely think that the lectures should be recorded and uploaded to canvas in the future.

I appreciated Vanden Boom writing his notes as he went, allowing for smooth timing and to return to any example problems we struggled with. He also gave anonymous polls during class on example problems to check our understanding before explaining the correct answer. This often helped students decide where they were lost or what concepts were unclear.
Even virtually, there was an excellent class environment that made it easy to ask questions.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student, especially if you have to take it for a prerequisite. It is a solid course.
I was fortunate to have gotten a really good professor, which I have heard can make or break your class. If you have taken AP AB Calc or something similar, then this course would be for you.
Yes, it's a great mathematics course that may should take, even if not necessary. I nothing else, it helps develop critical thinking skills.
Yes, I would recommend this course if it was necessary, but it is not as engaging as other courses.

If you want to take this course, make sure you have a strong background in Mathematics. A lot of the students taking it have taken BC calc, and are familiar with most, if not, all of the topics. This put students like myself who only took AB at a bit of a disadvantage. Also, do NOT be afraid to sneak your way into more reputable sections with better rated profs. Your experience with this course truly depends on your professor, so don't feel bad about switching profs if your section does not work for you!
No
Yes. If you need to finish a math requirement or you simply enjoy integral calculus, you should certainly take this course.
Yes; it is a standard math class that will teach you what you need to know for future classes.
Yes, I would strongly recommend this class. It is a good foundation for all classes and learning calculus is always a strong way to gain critical thinking skills.
Take it only for a STEM majo; if you need a quantitative reasoning credit do something else.
Yes. I think if you like math this is a course that you'll enjoy, and even if you only take it because it's a requirement, I think you'll still find the class okay.

This level of math is not for everyone so I would not recommend it if you do not need to take it. Some professors are not as good as others but my professor, Dr. VandenBoom was very helpful. For those interested in math, this is a nice continuation of calculus 1.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student if math is one of your requirements, and in general it taught topics that are very useful for many career paths.
Yes, because I enjoyed this class due to its clarity in instruction even on a virtual format.
Yes good course
I would. It's an interesting math class.
Maybe. Only really if they needed it as a pre requisite.

this course is all about the section teacher. tom vanden boom was great, but I heard bad things about oleksii. double check who your section teacher is if you can. this math class is a very common prerequisite but if you are a bio major, math 116 should be more interesting while covering the same concepts.
I would recommend this course! The workload isn't too much to handle and the peer tutors were such a great resource!
